Against the Kings, he scored a season-low 8 points and missed two crucial free throws down the stretch. Against the Warriors, he fouled Baron Davis on a 3-pointer late in the game and was later called for charging. Against the Clippers, he left Cuttino Mobley open for the winning 3-pointer.  After each of those games, Carter put much of the blame on himself and appeared uncharacteristically down.  But he made a renewed commitment to attacking the basket. In the final three games of the trip, Carter averaged 35.3 points and shot 66.1 percent from the field. He also averaged 12 free-throw attempts a game, evidence of his aggressiveness in the paint.  ''At the beginning of the trip, each individual had to step their game up, and I felt I had to do the same,'' Carter said Monday night. ''I felt that in the first three games, regardless of points, I didn't deliver because we didn't win the game. I'm just glad I could do it for my team.''  Carter is playing his best at a time when he is the subject of many trade rumors. Although the Nets' president, Rod Thorn, has said that players are worth more in trades when they are playing well, Carter might be making him think twice about any such decision.  The Nets also need Carter more than ever because they are without small forward Richard Jefferson, who missed the trip because of ankle surgery that could keep him out until early March. Jefferson was the Nets' second-leading scorer before he was injured.  Another good sign for the Nets was that their bench helped lift the burden of not having Jefferson. In each game, a different reserve stepped forward.  The rookie Hassan Adams took Jefferson's place in the starting lineup for the first three games, and Wright started the last two. Both were called on for their defense, and they delivered.  Wright was especially impressive. Before starting Saturday night's game against the Nuggets, he had not played in 12 of the previous 19 games. But he scored 11 points and slowed Anthony.  The reserve forward Bostjan Nachbar was averaging 17.7 points over a three-game stretch but became ill before the Jazz game and did not play. So House stepped in with his 19-point effort.  Moore had a fitting description for what these all-around contributions said about the Nets: ''We're a team.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets End 5-Game Trip By Making Their Point

content.text: In the excitement of a shootout against the Devils on Tuesday night, a game the Rangers felt they desperately needed to win, Marcel Hossa took the ice as the Rangers' eighth shooter.  He followed a trail of sharpshooting teammates, including Jaromir Jagr, Brendan Shanahan and Martin Straka. But if he was nervous in such a crucial spot, he betrayed none of it.  ''He just looked like the smoothest, coolest guy out there,'' Shanahan said.  As Hossa skated in on Devils goalie Martin Brodeur, he pulled Brodeur wide and calmly fired a shot into the upper left corner, then turned to smile at his teammates, who were celebrating wildly.  One more save by Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist, on Travis Zajac, and the Rangers were celebrating a 3-2 victory over a team that seems to bring out the best in them.  The victory pulled the Rangers (20-17-4) a point closer to the Devils (22-13-4), who lead the Atlantic Division. The Rangers, 4 points behind the Devils in second place, have won three of the teams' four meetings this season.  But the most important part of this one was mental.  Just four days earlier, the Rangers were mired in a seven-game losing streak. They ended it with a home victory Saturday against Washington, but beating a struggling team at home does not offer the same boost in confidence that beating a first-place team on the road does.  And they vanquished the Devils in spectacular fashion.  Lundqvist had stopped all 22 shots he had faced in the Rangers' four shootouts this season, a record that came to a screeching halt when Zach Parise scored on the Devils' first shot. In all, Lundqvist gave up three goals in the shootout. But Brodeur allowed goals to Michael Nylander Shanahan, Matt Cullen and Hossa.  It was the second time this season that Hossa won a shootout for the Rangers; he put a shot through the pads of Flyers goalie Antero Niittymaki in the 13th round on Oct. 7 in Philadelphia.  Hossa has scored only once in regulation this season. His shot against the Flyers, however, helped him climb a few notches up the shootout chart. Hossa said it had also increased his confidence in trying a far more difficult shot against Brodeur.  ''I was thinking I would go five-hole again, but maybe my brother scored too many goals on him five-hole so he would think I was going to do the same,'' Hossa said, laughing, referring to his brother Marian, a star forward for Atlanta who has scored 23 more goals than he has this season. ''This time I did a different thing and it went through.''  The Devils said they were happy to collect a point for taking the game to overtime. Jamie Langenbrunner's power-play goal with 4 minutes 12 seconds left in regulation allowed them to tie the score at 2-2.  ''It was a hard-earned point,'' Devils Coach Claude Julien said. ''We'll take it and move on.''  Langenbrunner had a chance to win the game in the shootout as well, as the Devils' seventh shooter, pulling Lundqvist wide and nearly stuffing in a backhand. But Lundqvist stretched his glove to the right post and nudged the puck aside.  That turn of events allowed Hossa to score the winner.  The Rangers played a solid game to reach the shootout. After falling behind, 1-0, in the first on a goal by John Madden, they came back on goals by Nylander and Petr Prucha before Langenbrunner tied it late.  The remarkable part of Prucha's goal was how the puck got to him. Jagr deflected a pass from defenseman Karel Rachunek with his right skate and sent it to a waiting Prucha, unguarded at the left post.  ''I tried to kick it in the net,'' Jagr said. ''I missed that. I wanted to go top shelf. I'll be working on it tomorrow.''  Shootouts, it seems, have become a specialty for the Rangers, who are now 5-1 in them. And they can turn to their secret weapon when they need to win one.  ''It was a terrific move,'' Renney said of Hossa's shot. ''This is one of the best goalies to ever play the game. Hoss should feel good about himself right about now.''  SLAP SHOTS  Rangers forward Jed Ortmeyer played his first game since doctors found he had a pulmonary embolism in August. He played only nine shifts, for 5 minutes 35 seconds of ice time. Forward Jarkko Immonen was a healthy scratch. ... Devils defenseman Colin White missed his fourth straight game with a groin injury.  HOCKEY
content.title: Hossa Delivers for Rangers in Shootout With Devils

content.text: After running through the gamut of emotions, from the highest highs late last week to another stupefying low Sunday afternoon, the Knicks were left with a bad case of whiplash.  Then again, the condition might simply have been a product of watching their shots fly in the opposite direction. The Knicks converted a season-low 34.5 percent of their field-goals attempts Sunday, in large part because 16 of their attempts were swatted away by the Los Angeles Clippers, who cruised to a 90-80 victory at the Staples Center.  Elton Brand accounted for eight of those blocks, a career high, and scored an efficient 32 points to ruin the Knicks' New Year's Eve. The defeat denied the Knicks (13-20) a chance to claim a share of first place in the Atlantic Division. It prevented them from recording a .500 record in December, leaving them 7-9. And, combined with Friday night's lopsided loss in Phoenix, it wiped out all the exhilaration of the previous two weeks. That triple-overtime victory last week against Detroit already seems like a distant memory.  ''I'd be lying if I told you I wasn't frustrated right now,'' forward David Lee said. ''All our guys are frustrated.''  The Knicks trailed wire to wire, by as many as 24 points, and never got closer than 10 in the second half. They also trailed by as many as 24 points in Phoenix, where they never got closer than 11. But the Clippers (14-16) are not the Suns, and Coach Isiah Thomas surely expected his team to have learned something in Saturday's extensive film session here.  But there are lessons that still elude them and the most damaging one is how to keep the offense rolling when Eddy Curry is double-teamed. The Clippers, like the Suns, crowded Curry every time he touched the ball. Curry made 5 of 13 shots, and six of his seven misses were blocked. He finished with 15 points.  ''It seemed like they were coming from everywhere tonight,'' Curry said.  The Knicks do not have the shooters to keep defenses honest. Indeed, their forward rotation is littered with players who have no reliable jump shot -- Lee, Jared Jeffries and Renaldo Balkman. Jeffries played just 15 minutes Sunday.  ''I don't think it's Eddy's fault, whatsoever,'' Lee said. ''He's getting double-teamed and guys need to step up and make a play, myself included.''  It would help to have the injured Quentin Richardson back. But the Knicks also need Curry to take the next step as a franchise player, and diversify his game.  ''It's just different because of how they're guarding Eddy now,'' Stephon Marbury said. ''Once Eddy understands that he's going to be double-teamed for the remainder of his career, it's going to be tough for us until he understands that. He's starting to learn that when the trap comes to kick it out right away and repost. This is all brand new to him.''  Thomas tried everything Sunday -- playing Curry and Jerome James as co-centers, benching Jeffries for long stretches, and leaning hard on the rookie Mardy Collins. Curry and Jamal Crawford were on the bench in the fourth quarter when a unit featuring James, Collins, Lee, Marbury and Channing Frye cut a 24-point deficit to 84-74 with 3 minutes 36 seconds to play. The Clippers responded with three quick baskets.  ''I was just searching, pushing every button I could push tonight,'' Thomas said. ''And I finally got a group out there that had some semblance of working together and I just tried to stick with it.''  While Richardson missed his eighth game in a row because of back spasms, the Knicks' guards had another terrible shooting performance. Crawford was 2 for 8 and Marbury 3 for 13. Collins, in his first game back from a suspension, was the best shooter, hitting 4 of 9 shots, including three 3-pointers. He finished with a career-high 11 points and is likely to keep his rotation spot while Richardson and Steve Francis recover from injuries.  ''He was definitely a bright spot,'' Thomas said of Collins. ''I hope I can keep finding him minutes.''  For Collins, every game is a chance to make a name for himself. Until then, the image of him is as the guy who committed the flagrant foul that set off the brawl with Denver.  ''It's definitely tough to be known, the first thing you come in the league, to be known as a guy that's like this and like that,'' Collins said. ''So my whole thing is to try to go out there and prove to them and show them I can actually play basketball, try to forget about the whole situation.''  REBOUNDS  Steve Francis was back in a suit and tie Sunday afternoon, resting his right knee (tendinitis). Francis played sparingly last week, when the Knicks desperately needed another guard, but he was limited. ''I can't do anything,'' Francis said. ''It's constant pain at all times. I couldn't run or stop.''  Nate Robinson, barred from attending N.B.A. games during his suspension, went to the U.C.L.A.-Washington game at Pauley Pavilion. Robinson played three years for Washington before being drafted by the Knicks in 2005.  PRO BASKETBALL  Correction:  January 3, 2007, Wednesday  A sports article on Monday about the Knicks' 90-80 loss to the Clippers in Los Angeles misidentified the team that drafted guard Nate Robinson in 2005. It was the Phoenix Suns, who selected him at the Knicks' request, then traded him and Quentin Richardson to the Knicks for Kurt Thomas the same day; the Knicks did not draft Robinson.
content.title: Knicks Have a Hard Time Dealing With Rejection

content.text: Coach Isiah Thomas looked ahead Tuesday, staring straight at Gilbert Arenas, whom the Knicks will somehow try to contain when they play the Wizards on Wednesday in Washington.  Arenas walked off the court Monday in Washington to a chorus of ''M.V.P! M.V.P!'' after he hit a 3-pointer at the buzzer to beat Utah, 114-111. He finished with 51 points, the third time this season he has scored more than 50.  Now it's the Knicks' turn.  Thomas said he would ask Stephon Marbury, Jared Jeffries and the rookie Renaldo Balkman to try to keep Arenas in line, which may be asking a lot from the Knicks, who often seem defensively challenged.  Marbury is generally known for his offensive skills, although he shut down Ray Allen in Seattle recently in a defensive performance that did not go unnoticed. Balkman, a forward, is still learning the finer points of the game. But Jeffries, another forward, has generally earned his living in the N.B.A. as a defensive demon.  Jeffries is an offensive liability who compensates with blocked shots, steals and rebounds. When he is playing well, he can have a noticeable effect on a game. Against the Sacramento Kings on Monday, Jeffries blocked a shot by Ron Artest 30 seconds into the game. Jeffries had two more blocks in the game, including one more on Artest, who ended up with only 12 points. The Knicks prevailed, 102-97.  Still, more often than not this season, the 6-foot-11 Jeffries has struggled to make an impact.  ''I feel like I definitely could do better,'' Jeffries said after Tuesday's practice.  Jeffries, who starts at small forward, missed the first 22 games of the season with a fractured left wrist. He returned Dec. 11, and in his fourth game back, he was suspended for four games for his role in a brawl with the Denver Nuggets.  In 13 games, Jeffries has averaged 5.6 points and 5.4 rebounds. He has not consistently been the player the Knicks coveted when they signed him to a five-year, $30 million deal in August. Monday's game was the perfect example. In the opening minute of the third quarter, Jeffries made a bad pass that led to a turnover and shot an air ball on a 3-point attempt.  Jeffries's struggles have opened the door to more minutes for David Lee, who might not be as imposing defensively but is better at finding ways to score and rebound.  ''Just not making mistakes, just being more active,'' Jeffries said when asked what areas of his game needed improvement. ''Not really thinking when I'm out there; just playing like a natural feel.''  There is no telling what defensive scheme the Knicks will use against the Wizards. Thomas said that Marbury would start off guarding Arenas; Marbury also defended well in the fourth quarter Monday against Kevin Martin.  But Jefferies, as a former Wizard, is more familiar with Arenas, who is averaging 30.2 points and has a knack for sinking game-winning shots.  Jeffries was drafted by the Wizards with the 11th overall pick in 2002, and he played the first four seasons of his career in Washington.  ''I played with him for a couple years,'' Jeffries said of Arenas. ''It's just a matter of trying to force him to do things. Keep him guessing. Don't let him get into a rhythm.''  Jeffries was a restricted free agent after last season, which meant the Wizards had the option of matching the Knicks' offer. They chose not to. But Jeffries said he expected a cordial reception from the fans Wednesday. He was more concerned about guarding Arenas.  ''The way he's playing right now, making pull-ups, getting to the rim, passing the ball, it's hard to say he really has a weakness,'' Jeffries said.  He'll try to find one.  BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Count on Jeffries To Help Quiet Arenas

content.text: The Nets' success was clear and emphatic Monday.  Jason Kidd, the 33-year-old captain, fell one rebound short of his 83rd career triple-double. Vince Carter made it look easy, scoring 31 points. The journeyman center Mikki Moore blocked a shot and then yelled so loudly and scowled so fiercely that he seemed to rattle a young girl sitting in the first row at Continental Arena.  Leading by as many as 27 points against the Indiana Pacers, the Nets won for the sixth time in their last eight games, 105-95. The game followed a disappointing defeat at Minnesota on Saturday night, when the Nets fell apart in the fourth quarter.  Weeks ago, such a deflating defeat would have probably sent the Nets (17-20) into a slide. But now they carry themselves with a winning swagger.  ''I think we've been competing at a high level in the sense of as a team,'' said Kidd, who had 19 points, 10 assists and 9 rebounds. ''It's not been just one person playing. I think everybody's been pitching in.''  The most unheralded contributor during the Nets' turnaround has been Moore. He replaced Nenad Krstic, who tore his anterior cruciate ligament last month.  Moore, acquired last summer from the Seattle SuperSonics for a second-round pick, has exceeded expectations as an off-the-bench energy player. Although he cannot recall being a first option on offense, Moore has been scoring at an unusual pace.  Moore scored 19 points Monday, the third time this season that he has matched or surpassed his previous career high, 18.  ''I'm having a good time out there,'' he said. ''The team is real unselfish, man. If the play is there for me to get the ball, they make sure I get the ball. If they're going to put that much trust in me, I've got to finish.''  Moore, who made his first four field-goal attempts, all dunks, made his biggest mark on defense in the third quarter. He swatted a layup attempt by Pacers center Jermaine O'Neal, screamed, flexed and stared ahead.  ''Anybody can score, but once you get a stop, once you make a team do what they don't want to do, you can make offensive runs,'' Moore said. ''You can make transition baskets easy off of defense.''  The Nets' offense was precise in the first quarter -- eight straight field goals over one stretch -- and late in the period, Kidd scored 7 consecutive points. The first 2 points came on a smart play in which he intercepted an outlet pass by Al Harrington, who led the Pacers with 18 points, and then drove for an easy layup.  He followed with a 16-foot bank shot over Jamaal Tinsley, and after making a free throw, he hit a fadeaway jumper to give the Nets their first double-digit lead of the game, 29-18, with 3 minutes 35 seconds to play in the quarter.  The Nets steadily pulled away in the second quarter, building a 21-point lead at halftime. They led by as many as 27 points in the third quarter. Through three quarters, the Nets were shooting 50.8 percent from the field and they held the Pacers (20-18) to 37.9 percent shooting. The statistics were skewed by the fact that the Nets entered the fourth quarter with a 25-point lead and were not at their sharpest.  Since filing for divorce last week, Kidd has been playing some of his best basketball of the season. By all indications, he has appeared as happy as ever during practices and games.  ''I think you could make the argument he is having as good a year as he's ever had,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''I think any time it is called into question that he is not where he was, that just fuels the fire, and that's what the great ones do.''  Kidd may be looking to add to his legacy. He addressed a report that he would be invited to join the United States national basketball team.  ''If that's the case, I would love to be a part of that team this summer to help try to regain that special feeling of winning in international ball,'' he said.  REBOUNDS  Marcus Williams, the Nets' rookie point guard, returned after a two-game absence because of strep throat, which left him bedridden for four days. Williams finished with 6 points, 3 rebounds and an assist in 11 minutes.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Get Unexpected Lift From Moore on Offense

content.text: With three games left before the season's mathematical midpoint, the Knicks' image remains a curious mosaic of contradictions.  After consecutive routs of three of the N.B.A.'s worst teams, Coach Isiah Thomas declared that the Knicks should now be expected to beat the N.B.A.'s worst teams. Then the Charlotte Bobcats came to New York and routed them by 16 points.  Weakened by suspensions and injuries in late December, the Knicks beat three top-tier opponents -- Utah, Chicago and Detroit. Faced with a string of sub-.500 opponents -- Sacramento, the Clippers, Portland, Seattle, Philadelphia and Charlotte -- the Knicks proceeded to go 3-3.  The Knicks have been lauded this season for their resilience. But their loss Friday to the Bobcats left them 2-20 in games they trailed at halftime.  For all the recent flashes of promise, the Knicks are 16-22 -- shaky enough to hold the 11th-best record in the Eastern Conference, but solid enough to be in contention for the Atlantic Division title and a playoff berth.  To put it more simply, the Knicks are a typical rebuilding project, albeit one with a massive payroll and a lot of former lottery picks in the rotation. They are young and inconsistent, teasing their fans with surprising victories and infuriating them with unforgivable defeats.  The Knicks are 11-11 since a 5-11 start, and there are certainly more wild fluctuations to come. The roster finally returned to full strength last week (minus guard Steve Francis, who has always been superfluous), so Thomas is again retooling the rotation and fiddling with the chemistry.  Quentin Richardson appears to be healthy after missing 11 games because of a back injury. He averaged 18 points, 8 rebounds, 3 assists and 2.5 steals in his first two games back, making a strong case to return to the starting lineup. That would force Thomas to send Jamal Crawford, Jared Jeffries or Channing Frye to the bench. The current lineup is 4-5, so Thomas would not be breaking up any magic combinations.  Nate Robinson, the other key player to return last week -- after a 10-game suspension for his role in the Dec. 16 brawl with Denver -- is not yet himself. Robinson vowed to suppress his wilder side, but he also seems to have lost his confident stride. He went scoreless in two games last week, going 0 for 4 from the field in 18 minutes. Yet he still managed to draw a technical foul Friday night. In the 5 minutes 48 seconds he played, Robinson had extensive conversations with two of the three referees.  Thomas had more options last week, but he relied primarily on eight players -- Eddy Curry, Stephon Marbury, David Lee, Jeffries, Frye, Crawford, Richardson and Robinson. Thomas still seems to be searching for the best way to deploy Jeffries and Lee, in particular.  Jeffries was signed last summer to bolster the Knicks' defense, but his lack of scoring punch can be a drag on the offense. Thomas played him just 16 minutes Friday (3 in the second half), preferring to use Richardson (38 minutes) and Lee (27 minutes), despite the Knicks' inability to contain the Bobcats' shooters.  The newly crowded frontcourt rotation has seemed to affect Lee the most. A linchpin of the Knicks' success in the weeks after the brawl, Lee lost some steam last week, averaging only 9 points and 5.5 rebounds in two games. He had been averaging a double-double.  And the Knicks continue to wait for Frye to become a reliable scoring threat. He had 10 points in the first quarter against Charlotte, but only 2 the rest of the night. Thomas continues to start Frye, but often leaves him on the bench in the fourth quarter.  By Feb. 1, the Knicks could just as easily be division leaders or bottom dwellers. Over the next 10 games, they play just four teams with winning records (Washington, Indiana, Phoenix and the Lakers). But they also have two games with the Miami Heat, whose losing record could be offset by the imminent return of Shaquille O'Neal.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: No Method to Knicks' Maddening First Half

content.text: Disaster took on many forms for the Knicks on Monday night. Had a 28-point first-quarter deficit been the worst of it, they might have left South Florida feeling grateful.  They had greater concerns, however, after being routed, 101-83, by the star-depleted Miami Heat at American Airlines Arena. Stephon Marbury's left knee again became too painful to bear, and he played only 15 minutes 58 seconds before leaving the game for good. His status for Wednesday's home game against the Phoenix Suns is uncertain.  Marbury, who routinely plays hurt and nearly always vows to be back by the next game, could not make that declaration this time.  ''I don't know yet,'' he said. ''To really be honest, I don't know.''  Had Marbury been at full strength, the Knicks (18-25) would have probably still been blown out by the energized Heat (19-22). Miami looked that determined. The Knicks looked that disoriented, at least in the first quarter.  After Quentin Richardson made a 3-pointer for a 3-2 lead, the Heat scored 27 consecutive points -- a Miami franchise record. The Knicks went 8:14 without scoring until Eddy Curry made a driving layup to cut the deficit to 29-5.  Coach Isiah Thomas called timeouts, to no avail. He sent in Jamal Crawford for Jared Jeffries and David Lee for Curry, and later sent in Nate Robinson and Malik Rose for Marbury and Channing Frye. The Heat kept scoring, and the Knicks kept missing.  ''It seems like the court's tilted, like they're running downhill, shooting layups and making 3's,'' Lee said. ''And we're going uphill just to get the ball across halfcourt and try to get a shot up.''  It was the kind of display one might expect when the defending champion plays one of the league's weaker teams. Except that the Heat was missing its two biggest stars -- Shaquille O'Neal and Dwyane Wade -- and the Knicks had lately appeared to be stronger than this.  Thomas was forced to concede the obvious, that the Knicks had perhaps been overconfident. ''Probably,'' he said.  Thomas had far worse things to say about his team.  ''This is the first time I've been with this group where we didn't show up to compete,'' he said. ''Maybe respect had something to do with it.''  The disbelief in Thomas's expression was matched by the exasperation in his players' voices. No one disputed the conclusions. They just could not fathom how it all happened.  ''We don't have the luxury of taking anybody lightly,'' Richardson said. ''We're not that good.''  Even without Wade (who has a sprained ankle) and O'Neal (who missed his 36th game after knee surgery), the Heat had a stockpile of talented and accomplished veterans: Alonzo Mourning, Gary Payton, Jason Williams and Udonis Haslem among them.  ''They performed flawlessly,'' said Ron Rothstein, the Heat's acting head coach while Pat Riley recovers from surgery.  With the ageless Mourning setting the tone, the Heat outrebounded the Knicks, 45-33. Mourning blocked four shots, including consecutive swats of Lee in the first quarter, and finished with seven rebounds.  Payton, who is also in his twilight, started for Wade and collected 10 points and 13 assists. Williams had 20 points and 7 assists. Jason Kapono scored 12 points in the first quarter -- matching the Knicks' team output -- and finished with 22.  The Knicks trailed by 40-12 at the end of the first quarter and were down by 15 points at halftime, when Marbury said he was done for the night.  Crawford (23 points) and Curry (26 points) led a second-half rally, and the Knicks cut their deficit to 6 points with 8:10 left in the game. They were down by just 8 points with 5:37 left, but Williams hit two 3-pointers and Antoine Walker followed with another 3-pointer to kill the Knicks' surge.  ''By the time we showed up, the game was over,'' Thomas said.  When all the self-flogging was over, the attention turned to Marbury's health. He has had trouble with the knee for more than a month, since banging the patellar tendon in a game Dec. 15 at Indiana. But Marbury has not missed a game this season and has not flinched at playing 40 minutes on many nights.  The knee had not been an issue until Saturday, when Marbury landed awkwardly late in the fourth quarter at Indiana. He spent the final 1:26 on the bench. On Monday morning, Marbury dismissed concerns about the knee, saying it had improved greatly after a therapeutic massage that broke up scar tissue.  But he passed up some early scoring opportunities and went to the bench for good with 4:51 left in the first half.  ''Just running on it, it just got really sore,'' he said. ''It's just going to take some time for it to heal a little bit.''  Asked if that meant he might have to take time off, Marbury said, ''I don't know, I'm just going to see.'' But, he reiterated, ''it's not something that I'm worried about.''  With Steve Francis still in Houston -- presumably rehabilitating his own sore knee -- the Knicks can ill afford to lose Marbury. There are no indications that Francis will return anytime soon, if he does at all. Last season, the Knicks went 5-17 in games that Marbury missed.  ''I don't even want to think that way, 5-17,'' Thomas said. ''I mean, that wouldn't be good right now.''  REBOUNDS  Isiah Thomas said he had no update on the status of Steve Francis, who left for Houston three weeks ago to rehabilitate a sore knee. Reminded that he had said he hoped Francis would return soon, Thomas said with a chuckle, ''I still hope that.'' ... The Heat's previous franchise record for consecutive points scored was 26, against the Golden State Warriors on March 24, 1995.  BASKETBALL
content.title: After Loss, Concerns About Effort, and Marbury's Knee

content.text: The Yankees continued their attempt to trade Randy Johnson yesterday, talking with multiple teams about a deal. The most likely match remains Johnson's former team, the Arizona Diamondbacks, but Arizona has not been granted a 72-hour window to speak with him. Johnson must approve a trade and it is not clear how the Diamondbacks would afford him.  While the Johnson talks have absorbed most of the Yankees' attention, they have other needs. They are still interested in signing a first baseman, with Travis Lee emerging as an option if they cannot agree to terms with Doug Mientkiewicz on a one-year deal.  Signing Mientkiewicz is the Yankees' priority because of his exceptional glove and decent left-handed bat. Lee is also a left-hander and a strong defender, but he hit only .224 for Tampa Bay last season. He played briefly for the Yankees in 2004.  Mientkiewicz had back surgery last August after hitting .283 for Kansas City. He has discussed a one-year deal with the Yankees.  The Yankees already have two right-handers at first base in Andy Phillips and Josh Phelps, with only one expected to make the team. If they want to add another right-handed first baseman, they could still turn to the free agent Craig Wilson, who hit .212 in 40 games for the Yankees last season.  For now, the Yankees do not have a roster spot for Bernie Williams, the longtime center fielder, and they also need a backup infielder. They would also like another left-handed reliever to complement Mike Myers. They have signed the left-hander Ben Kozlowski, a minor leaguer, but have made no formal offers to veteran left-handers on the free-agent market.  BASEBALL
content.title: Yanks Still Seek Help at First

content.text: A cruel sort of familiarity came over the Knicks last night, as they stared at the wrong end of a lopsided score and watched another star player limp away. A few more games like this could destroy their morale, if not their season.  The injured star was center Eddy Curry, who has become the Knicks' most irreplaceable player. He strained his left calf muscle early in the fourth quarter, just as the Phoenix Suns surged to a 17-point lead at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks avoided the rout, losing, 112-107, but they could not avoid another night of furrowed brows and deep sighs.  Stephon Marbury was already out, resting a sore knee that knocked him out of Monday night's blowout loss in Miami. Marbury said he planned to be back tomorrow when the Heat go to the Garden, but now it is Curry whose status is up in the air.  The Knicks offered no official prognosis, and Coach Isiah Thomas said, ''I don't know what his situation will be.''  The most optimistic voice belonged to Curry, who predicted he would be fine for tomorrow's showdown with Shaquille O'Neal. But Curry said he could not be sure until he sees how the calf responds overnight. A similar injury cost Curry five games last season, but he said this one was not as severe.  ''Definitely not as bad,'' Curry said. ''I'm not expecting to miss any time, but you don't really know with these type of things.''  According to Curry, the team doctors believe the injury is ''fairly significant, but they think there's a good chance I'll play Friday.''  The Suns (34-8) won their 15th straight game, tying a franchise record they set earlier this season. Amare Stoudemire led the way, scoring 26 of his 30 points in the second half. Steve Nash, who is sprinting toward a possible third straight Most Valuable Player award, had 22 points and 14 assists.  The Knicks (18-26) fell eight games below .500, matching their low point of the season. After briefly making a run at the Atlantic Division lead, the Knicks have lost five of seven games and are three and a half games behind Toronto.  Still, the Knicks nearly survived Marbury's absence last night. They cannot afford to lose Curry, their leading scorer and the focal point of their offensive system. No one on the roster can do what he does.  ''I don't even want to think about it,'' Jamal Crawford said of losing Curry.  Curry was barreling toward a career game, scoring 21 points in the first half and overpowering Stoudemire.  ''He's a load,'' Suns Coach Mike D'Antoni said.  Curry said the calf began to feel tight when he started the third quarter. It was evident in his play. Curry picked up two quick fouls guarding Stoudemire and stopped attacking on offense. The training staff had Curry put a sleeve over the calf to keep it loose.  ''I kind of knew when it started to tighten up that if I push off on it too fast that it'd be a problem,'' Curry said. ''So I kind of had to gauge myself out there and pick my spots.''  But 1 minute 20 seconds into the fourth quarter, Curry caught a pass on the right block and spun aggressively toward the basket for a layup. He came down with a wince and could not run back up the court. He limped to the sideline and later retreated to the locker room.  ''It's just in my nature to get the ball and try to score,'' Curry said. ''It just kind of gave out on me.''  The Knicks trailed by 87-70 when Curry left. Crawford, as he so often has, seized the moment. He scored 23 points in the fourth quarter, and along with David Lee, nearly rallied the Knicks to the comeback.  Crawford hit two free throws with 41.5 seconds left to cut the deficit to 6 points, then hit two more to make it a 5-point game with 25.6 seconds left. But the Knicks ran out of time, and Nash made three of four free throws to close out the victory.  Crawford, starting in place of Marbury, had 29 points and 11 assists and played all 48 minutes. Curry finished with 25 points in 31 minutes. Lee had 17 points and 14 rebounds off the bench. Nate Robinson, who played most of the second half next to Crawford, also had 17 points but shot 5 of 19 from the field.  Quentin Richardson, a former Sun and the Knicks' best shooter, missed all five of his shots and went scoreless in 24 minutes.  Phoenix pulled away by hitting seven 3-pointers in the second half (after making just two in the first half) and by getting to the foul line. They made 22 of 31 free throws in the second half. Without Curry, the Knicks' inside game dried up.  Marbury watched the game in a suit and tie, but before tip-off he said he was ''definitely playing Friday'' when the Heat -- with O'Neal and Dwyane Wade back in the lineup -- visits the Garden. Miami routed the Knicks by 18 points Monday.  The Knicks have weathered the absence of several players already, and Thomas said they could survive Curry's as well.  ''It'd be tough, but we'll manage,'' he said. ''We'll find a way to make it work.''  REBOUNDS  Stephon Marbury's troublesome left knee felt good enough to run yesterday but not ready for jumping and cutting. He said that another 48 hours of rest would be enough and that he had no doubt about playing tomorrow night. Marbury said the knee will not be pain free when he returns, but it will be much better than it was when he was forced to sit out the second half of Monday's loss at Miami. ''These two days are going to be huge for me,'' Marbury said. ''It's just like more stiff than hurting. The pain part is gone, as far as the way how it felt when I initially did it.'' Marbury said he had already adjusted his game to compensate for the knee, which he originally injured Dec. 15. ''I'm playing smarter,'' he said. ''I wasn't going to the basket like how I did four or five years ago.''  For the second straight game, Jared Jeffries opened the second half on the bench. He was replaced by Nate Robinson and did not return until the final 25.6 seconds of the fourth quarter. Jeffries has been ineffective lately and was booed by fans several times last night. ''We depend on him to bring energy,'' Isiah Thomas said before the game. ''It won't necessarily show up on the stat sheet, but he's got to find a way to affect the game with his energy.''  BASKETBALL
content.title: Knicks Avoid Rout, but Not Another Loss

content.text: With a month to go before pitchers and catchers report to camp, the Mets' off-season priority of landing a top-flight starting pitcher remains unfulfilled. Instead, General Manager Omar Minaya indicated yesterday that the Mets would divide eight into three and hope that a group consisting of John Maine, Oliver Pérez, Mike Pelfrey, Philip Humber, Alay Soler, Dave Williams, Jorge Sosa and Jason Vargas will fill the Nos. 3, 4 and 5 spots in the rotation.  Minaya was straightforward about the team's pitching strategy during a conference call in which the Mets announced their two latest free-agent signings -- Sosa and the left-handed reliever Scott Schoeneweis.  This off-season has been somewhat frustrating for the Mets because they have been unable to acquire an ace pitcher, even though they are willing to spend a considerable amount of money. The Mets bid nearly $40 million for the negotiating rights to the Japanese pitcher Daisuke Matsuzaka, only to learn that Boston bid more. They were apparently willing to give the free agent Barry Zito $80 million or $90 million in a long-term deal, but the Giants snared him with a $126 million offer.  Minaya said yesterday that there were few pitchers left on the free-agent market that interested him and that the Mets would probably not add anyone before they report to Port St. Lucie, Fla., next month.  It is a team in which Tom Glavine and Orlando Hernández, both over 40 years old, have the only two guaranteed spots in the rotation. Then comes the group of eight, presumably led by Maine and Pérez, who pitched well under pressure in last year's National League Championship Series. There is also Sosa, who agreed to a $1.25 million deal and may also be considered for a role in the bullpen.  ''This is the group we are going to go in with and it is going to be fun to watch these guys go at it,'' Minaya said of the competition that will ensue in spring training. It will be even more fun for Minaya if some of the eight candidates pitch well.  The 33-year-old Schoeneweis, meanwhile, agreed to a three-year, $10.8 million deal. He has been a starter, long reliever, setup man and an occasional closer, but Minaya said yesterday that he would most likely be used in the seventh and eighth innings because he produces ground balls and does not give up many home runs.  The Mets also announced that they had signed two reserve players, Endy Chávez and Ramón Castro, to new deals. The speedy Chávez will make $1.75 million, a big jump from the $700,000 he made in 2005 as a bargain-basement pickup for the Mets.  Chávez had an excellent 2006 season, batting .306 with 22 doubles, and he made a spectacular catch in Game 7 of the N.L.C.S., robbing the St. Louis Cardinals' Scott Rolen of a two-run home run. The feat was to no avail as the Mets lost the game.  Castro is guaranteed $850,000 next season, only $50,000 more than he made in 2006, when he missed a chunk of the season with a knee injury. He remains the team's primary backup catcher.  SOSA AND RANGERS CLOSE -- Sammy Sosa and the Texas Rangers are negotiating a minor league contract. Sosa, 38, has not played since the 2005 season. He had a second workout for the Rangers on Monday, then had dinner with General Manager Jon Daniels and other team officials. An agreement appears very likely. (AP)  VIZCAÍNO AND YANKEES REACH DEAL -- Luis Vizcaíno and the Yankees reached agreement yesterday on a one-year contract worth $3 million. The Diamondbacks traded Vizcaíno and three minor leaguers to the Yankees this month for Randy Johnson.  Vizcaíno was 4-6 last season with a 3.58 earned run average in 70 games and made $1,775,000. Vizcaíno, a 32-year-old right-hander, is 25-23 with a 4.24 E.R.A. in eight seasons with Oakland, Milwaukee, the Chicago White Sox and Arizona. (AP)  LIDGE AVOIDS ARBITRATION -- Brad Lidge, who blew a career-high six save chances last season, including four before the All-Star Game break, agreed to a one-year, $5.35 million contract with Houston yesterday. Lidge was 1-5 with a 5.28 E.R.A. and 32 saves, but his struggles led Manager Phil Garner to adopt a closer-by-committee approach for part of the season. (AP)  DEVIL RAYS' DUKES CHARGED -- The Tampa Bay Devil Rays prospect Elijah Dukes was arrested Monday and charged with misdemeanor marijuana possession after a traffic stop. The 22-year-old Dukes, who lives in nearby Brandon, Fla., was pulled over in his 2006 Dodge Charger on Monday night because of a loud music violation, the police said yesterday. A police officer smelled marijuana, and a police dog found less than 2 grams of marijuana in the car's center console, the police said.  Dukes, a switch-hitting outfielder who was the team's third-round draft pick in 2002, has a history of problems on and off the field. Dukes was suspended for 15 games at Class AAA Durham last year for disciplinary reasons. He was suspended for five games by the International League after he was ejected for arguing balls and strikes. (AP)  CREDE AGREES TO DEAL -- Third baseman Joe Crede and the Chicago White Sox agreed yesterday to a one-year, $4.94 million contract and avoided arbitration. Crede, 28, hit .283 last season with 30 home runs and 94 runs batted in. He had a .978 fielding percentage in 150 games. (AP)  ZAMBRANO MAKES HIGHEST REQUEST -- Cubs pitcher Carlos Zambrano asked for $15.5 million in salary arbitration yesterday. Zambrano, who went 16-7 for the Chicago last year and made $6.65 million, was offered $11,025,000 by the Cubs. His request and the club's offer were the highest numbers traded this year. (AP)  BASEBALL: ROUNDUP
content.title: Mets Hope Their New Math Leaves Them With 5 Starters

content.text: On the afternoon that followed the most disturbing night of their season, only two developments could have soothed the Knicks: a positive report on Stephon Marbury's knee or an N.B.A. edict canceling the rest of their games this week.  Neither event materialized Tuesday, leaving the Knicks (18-25) to contemplate Marbury's probable absence and the daunting sight of the Phoenix Suns and the Miami Heat.  Marbury said his left knee felt better, but that was after a morning of treatment and an afternoon of rest. Marbury called himself day to day. Coach Isiah Thomas glumly called him doubtful for Wednesday night's game against the Suns at Madison Square Garden.  Marbury has tendinitis, and there is no cure except rest. The pain flares up when he bangs the knee or lands awkwardly, as he did Saturday night in Indiana. Marbury said there was no plan for an extended rest; he will play if the knee feels right, or sit out if it does not. That is a decision he may be making daily for the rest of the season.  There is no good time for Marbury, the Knicks' starting point guard, to miss games. But this week ranks among the worst possible. The Suns (33-8), who have the league's second-best record, have won 14 consecutive games after their 127-105 victory at Washington on Tuesday night.  ''They're the best team in the league,'' Thomas said without prompting, ''and it definitely will be a challenging game for us, because they create so many mismatches for us. They're faster at a lot of positions, and their speed is really overwhelming sometimes.''  The Knicks were routed in Phoenix last month, 108-86. The Suns raced to a 34-14 lead in the first 12 minutes, which ranked as the Knicks' worst first quarter until this week. And Marbury was generally healthy for that game.  Marbury played just 16 minutes in Monday's 101-83 loss in Miami before bowing out because of pain in his knee. He was on the court for most of the first quarter, when the Heat scored 27 straight points and took a 40-12 lead. Miami performed these feats without its top two players, Shaquille O'Neal and Dwyane Wade.  It all prompted the harshest criticism Thomas had dispensed since becoming coach last June. ''We didn't show up,'' he said. ''We did not come to compete.''  But by the time the Knicks concluded a two-hour practice Tuesday, Thomas seemed ready to move on. He declined invitations to revisit his anger or to criticize his players further.  ''We're not going to dwell on it,'' he said. ''It happened, it's over, we lost and they won.''  Thomas called the first quarter Monday night ''definitely out of character for us'' and said his team ''responded today with a good practice.''  For the Knicks' sake, it better have been their best of the season. They could get run off their own court by Phoenix. On Friday, the Heat visits the Garden and is likely to have Wade and O'Neal healthy and in uniform. The Los Angeles Lakers visit next Tuesday.  The Knicks need a quick recovery by Marbury. But they also need their two starting forwards to find themselves.  Jared Jeffries played just four minutes Monday night, and Channing Frye played 14. They combined for zero points and zero defense. Thomas waved off any concerns, however, and said he had no plans to alter his starting lineup or his rotation.  ''We definitely can't base anything on last night's performance of any of our players,'' he said. Asked why he never put Jeffries -- generally regarded as the Knicks' best defender -- back on the court, Thomas said: ''Nobody was playing well. And the only reason why I played the guys that I played is because it's a rule that you had to have five people out on the floor.''  Recent games suggested that the struggles of Frye and Jeffries are not an aberration but a trend. Over the past two games, Frye has logged just 24 minutes -- the fewest he had played in any two-game stretch this season. His production was dismal: 6 points, 3 rebounds and 8 fouls, including a disqualification against Indiana. Frye has scored in double figures just once in the past four games.  In the same span, Jeffries has collected 10 points, 10 rebounds, 3 steals, 4 blocks and 7 turnovers. His defense has been spotty.  REBOUNDS  There are indications that Steve Francis -- the Knicks' other point guard with knee trouble -- may be ready to return soon. Francis, who has been rehabilitating in Houston, began running this week. ''He said last night that he felt as good as he's felt in a while,'' said his agent, Jeff Fried. ''There's definitely improvement.'' Francis should be re-evaluated by doctors this week. If all goes well, it is conceivable that he would return to New York next week and continue his rehabilitation with the team. Francis would still need time to regain his conditioning and practice with the team before returning to the rotation.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: After Blowout Loss, Knicks Go From the Heat to the Frying Pan

content.text: In an effort to raise the performance standards of their bullpens, teams have raised the standard of living for the pitchers who populate those bullpens. The more important they are perceived to be, the more money middle relievers are earning.  In an era when starting pitchers last fewer innings, middle relievers have become more important. A manager needs one or more pitchers to get him from the starter to the closer. With an increase in competition for good relief pitching, teams are offering relievers more money. That is a welcome development for a group that has always been the lowest paid on the field.  According to the players union's annual study of major league salaries, relievers had an average salary of $1,433,992 last season, up from $1,316,384 in 2005. The averages include the salaries of high-priced closers like Mariano Rivera and Billy Wagner.  Average salaries for other players ranged from $2,793,608 for second basemen to $5,872,629 for third basemen. First basemen and designated hitters were also over $5.5 million, and starting pitchers and outfielders were just under $5 million.  The Baltimore Orioles did more than their share this winter to raise the average salary of relievers. They signed Danys Báez to a three-year, $19 million contract; Jamie Walker for three years and $12 million; and Chad Bradford for three years and $10.5 million. The Mets signed Scott Schoeneweis for three years and $10.8 million. The Angels signed Justin Speier for four years and $18 million.  ''Omar always has been a believer in a good bullpen; I brought that belief here,'' Jim Duquette, the Orioles' general manager, said, referring to Omar Minaya, the Mets' general manager, with whom he worked in New York.  Minaya, in his second year as the Mets' chief tactician, built a strong bullpen for the 2006 season and needed it when injuries crippled the rotation late in the year. This year again, Minaya has sought to bolster the bullpen.  Besides Schoeneweis, the Mets have added Ambiorix Burgos in a trade with Kansas City and Jorge Sosa as a free agent to go with Wagner, Aaron Heilman, Guillermo Mota (after his season-opening 50-game steroids suspension), Pedro Feliciano and Duaner Sánchez, who is coming back from a shoulder separation.  ''A good bullpen makes your starters better,'' Minaya said. ''Your starters have a different feeling knowing the bullpen is there.''  A strong bullpen, Minaya believes, is a pennant-winning ingredient, and the Mets fell one victory short of demonstrating that last season. The Mets had the best bullpen in the National League, finishing the season with a .681 winning percentage (32-15) and a 3.28 earned run average.  Besides the Mets, the teams that have done the most to strengthen their bullpens this winter are the Orioles, whose bullpen was 13th in the American League last season; Cleveland (11th); Boston (9th); and Atlanta (10th in the N.L.).  ''We tried to invest dollars in a frontline starter,'' Minaya said. ''We weren't able to get one. Instead of investing dollars in a mediocre market, I said, 'Who is the best reliever in the market?' and it was Schoeneweis.''  The Orioles needed a wholesale upgrade to their bullpen because it had a .432 winning percentage (19-25) and a 5.27 E.R.A.  ''We blew 18 games where we had a lead or were tied after six innings last year,'' Duquette said. ''It seemed a lot worse having lived it. We felt we wanted to shorten the games.''  The Indians have pursued the same goal with the signing of Keith Foulke, Joe Borowski, Roberto Hernández and Aaron Fultz.  ''We scored the second-most runs in the league and our starters' E.R.A. was third in the league,'' General Manager Mark Shapiro said. ''I knew what I had to do.''  Shapiro said the offense that has developed in the American League has placed a greater strain on starting pitchers, making deeper bullpens necessary.  ''With strict pitch counts and starters not going far into games, you don't see guys throwing 280 innings,'' Shapiro said. ''The need for a deeper bullpen is there.''  The Indians traded their closer, Bob Wickman, to Atlanta last season. Shapiro said he expected Foulke or Borowski to replace him this year. The Red Sox are also looking for a closer because they want to make Jonathan Papelbon a starter.  Joel Piñeiro, whom they signed as a free agent after Seattle did not tender him a contract, could become the closer, or the Red Sox could start him and leave Papelbon as the closer. ''We don't have one person designated as the closer yet, but we certainly will by the time the season breaks,'' Theo Epstein, the Boston general manager, said.  Rollins Is High on Phillies  Phillies shortstop Jimmy Rollins might have become a little too enthusiastic at the team's winter promotional tour last week. ''I think we're the team to beat in the N.L. East -- finally,'' he declared.  The Phillies finished last season 12 games behind the Mets. They scored the most runs in the league, but they tied for allowing the second-most runs. They cannot expect their best player of 2006, Ryan Howard, to have a better season.  Rollins did not explain why he thought they were the team to beat, and in any event, Phillies General Manager Pat Gillick did not agree.  ''I think the team to beat is the incumbent,'' Gillick said. ''The Mets are probably the team to beat. I think we're going to be much better than we were last year, but the Mets are the team to beat.''  Injury Clause for Drew  In the wrangling over outfielder J. D. Drew's contract with the Red Sox, the agent Scott Boras made sure Drew would be guaranteed more money ($42 million) than he would have earned ($33 million) had he not opted out of the last three years of his five-year, $55 million contract with the Dodgers.  The Red Sox have an out for the last two years or the last year of the five-year, $70 million deal. If Drew winds up on the disabled list for 35 days with a baseball injury to his right shoulder in the third or fourth year, the Red Sox can terminate the rest of the contract  Word out of the Drew camp was it agreed to the out clause to allow the Red Sox' doctor to save face after a second opinion supposedly found nothing suspicious about Drew's shoulder. But the final structure of the contract seems to enable Boras to save face because he recommended that Drew walk away from the Dodgers' deal. Had the Red Sox contract extended the out clause to the final three years, Drew could have wound up with only $28 million.  On a conference call Friday, Boras and Theo Epstein, the Red Sox' general manager, called the contract issues minor.  If Drew's shoulder could cost him $28 million, or 40 percent of the contract, a reporter asked, how could it be considered minor? ''Every contract in baseball has certain contingencies that can turn it from guaranteed to nonguaranteed and you don't call those major parts of the contract,'' Epstein said. ''They are minor parts of the contract.''  Epstein was presumably referring to routine provisions that bar players from engaging in potentially dangerous activities like skydiving or racecar driving. A player's surgically repaired throwing shoulder does not quite fit into that category. Boras was more determined with his spin.  ''When you talk about the status of the contract,'' Boras said, ''guarantee provisions are not customarily applicable in normal major league contracts. In this contract, the guarantee provision is in place with the exception of a very, very myopic element of this, so this is something that is certainly treated for all intents and purposes as a $70 million contract.''  Guarantee provisions ''are not customarily applicable'' in normal major league contracts? Boras would be hard pressed to name one major free agent contract he has negotiated that-has not been guaranteed. The one for Alex Rodriguez? Barry Zito? Drew's Dodgers' contract?  ON BASEBALL
content.title: Middle Relievers Are Moving Front and Center

content.text: At the Final Four in Boston last April, the North Carolina women's basketball team saw a night full of promise dissolve into a disquieting mess.  The top-seeded Tar Heels lost in a semifinal to Maryland, which went on to win the national championship against Duke. North Carolina guard Ivory Latta said the flight home was filled with quiet tears.  Weeks and months passed, and Latta refused to watch the film from that game.  But on Friday, as the undefeated Tar Heels prepared for Sunday's game against Maryland, North Carolina Coach Sylvia Hatchell figured the time was right. Her players sat and stomached last season's end.  ''Man, it was depressing,'' Latta said. ''It was very hard to watch.''  But Latta said the film was also helpful. The players noticed simple mistakes they had made and vowed not to repeat them. At the Comcast Center on Sunday, the second-ranked Tar Heels took their long-awaited shot at the No. 3 Terrapins. This time, they walked off the court delighted, with an 84-71 victory that snapped Maryland's 19-game home winning streak before a crowd of 17,950 that was the largest to attend an Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season women's game.  ''Playing against North Carolina, playing against Duke, the revenge factor is so, so big right now,'' said Maryland forward Laura Harper, whose team lost to Duke, 81-62, on Jan. 13. ''They come ready to play us.''  For a time, North Carolina's victory looked as if it would come easily. The Tar Heels (23-0, 7-0) raced to a 20-point second-half lead behind the shooting of Latta, who made six 3-pointers and finished with 32 points.  But Maryland (21-2, 5-2) responded with a furious comeback that was led by the senior guard Shay Doron, who scored 13 of her 19 points in the second half. With 3 minutes 13 seconds left, Doron converted a 15-footer, pulling the Terrapins to 67-66.  ''She just kept putting them up, making shots and all,'' Hatchell said. ''But, you know, that's Maryland; I knew they could score like that.''  The Tar Heels, who entered the game as the nation's top-scoring team, can pounce quickly, too. They closed the game with a 17-5 run, and revenge was theirs.  When Maryland, Duke and North Carolina reached the Final Four last season, it was the first time a conference had placed three teams in the national semifinals; the A.C.C. had never sent more than one.  This season, the three A.C.C. powers have a combined record of 65-2, with the two losses coming within their impressive triumvirate. Maryland plays host to Duke on Feb. 18 but will not face North Carolina again in the regular season. North Carolina plays host to Duke on Feb. 8 before visiting the Blue Devils on Feb. 25.  Sunday's game became a sellout more than two weeks ago. The atmosphere and the national-television audience might have caused some early-game jitters for the Terrapins. Maryland missed 15 of its first 18 field-goal attempts and committed 10 turnovers in the first 10 minutes.  ''Anxiousness, nerves, whatever you want to call it,'' Maryland Coach Brenda Frese said. ''But at the same time, we have played on the biggest stage before.''  With 30 seconds remaining in the first half and North Carolina leading, 33-27, Maryland guard Kristi Toliver was hounded by two defenders as she struggled to bring the ball across midcourt. Frese stomped the floor and yelled to a referee, frustrated that a foul had not been called. She received a technical foul, and Latta made both free throws, giving the Tar Heels an 8-point halftime lead. Latta made four 3-pointers in the first 4:50 of the second half, putting North Carolina ahead by 20.  COLLEGE BASKETBALL
content.title: North Carolina Exacts Revenge While Remaining Undefeated

content.text: Jason Kidd hit a shot Friday night that had his teammate Hassan Adams running in place and screaming on the sideline like a child in a schoolyard. The shot left many in Continental Arena with ear-to-ear grins, wide-eyed looks and hanging jaws.  Yet that may not have been the most spectacular thing they witnessed.  That distinction might belong to the Nets' shaking off an 18-0 deficit and defeating the Chicago Bulls, 91-86, in their first game of the new year.  The Nets (14-18) showed the type of resiliency they could only have dreamed of through their disappointing first 31 games of the season.  ''To me, the most impressive thing is, compared to some prior games that we've had, we kept our composure, we kept our poise,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''We didn't break.''  Chicago got out to that 18-0 lead by hitting 7 of its first 10 shots and forcing the Nets into four turnovers. The Nets missed their first nine shots and did not score until Richard Jefferson hit a free throw 6 minutes 34 seconds into the game.  That start was a distant memory by the beginning of the fourth quarter, when the Bulls led by only 2 points. The Nets executed in those final 12 minutes, yet another quality they have lacked for much of the season. Nine times this season, the Nets have squandered leads in the final six minutes.  But Friday night, their execution was punctuated by several timely shots late in the game.  Vince Carter, who led the Nets with 21 points, hit a long jumper over Kirk Hinrich with 1:05 to play that gave the Nets an 85-84 lead they did not relinquish.  On the Bulls' next possession, Kidd (17 points, 10 rebounds, 7 assists, 5 steals) slapped the ball from Ben Gordon's hands. He raced the other way for an uncontested layup that gave the Nets an 87-84 lead with 53 seconds left.  That play provided a prelude to his circus shot.  Kidd drove past Adrian Griffin along the baseline and into the middle of the lane. With Wallace in his way, Kidd turned his back to the basket and flicked the ball over his head with his left hand. The shot banked in to give the Nets an 89-84 advantage with 15 seconds to play.  ''I was a little stuck,'' Kidd said, ''and I just threw it up, hoping that it would just hit the rim and kind of kill time.''  Small forward Richard Jefferson, who scored 18 points, called it ''one of the craziest on-purpose shots I have ever seen at the end of the game.''  Adams said: ''It was crazy that he did that. It felt like it was in rhythm, like he'd been doing that, like a go-to move.''  In the fourth quarter, forward Bostjan Nachbar made two 3-pointers for the Nets. He was making his first start of the season, and he tied a season high with 16 points.  The Nets have won three games in a row for the first time this season and may finally be able to speak with some confidence, having beaten the Bulls (19-14), one of the Eastern Conference's best teams.  The Nets won the game without Jason Collins, their starting power forward, who missed the game with a strained lower back.  The Nets will have little time to celebrate. They travel to Cleveland on Saturday for a game against the Cavaliers and LeBron James.  At this time a year ago, the Nets were in the midst of a 10-game winning streak. Later in the season, the Nets had a 14-game winning streak that created a bravado they relied on for the rest of their schedule.  On Thursday, Carter reflected on those winning streaks by saying, ''We just felt unbeatable.''  He added: ''It's just not the case right now. We feel like we have to win by any means necessary. Last year, we kind of felt, especially during those two win streaks, even when we were losing, we still felt like we could walk on the floor and beat anybody.''  Slowly but surely, the Nets are trying to regain that swagger, one trick shot at a time.  REBOUNDS  Nets center Nenad Krstic, who sustained a season-ending tear of his anterior cruciate ligament two weeks ago, spoke with reporters for the first time since then before Friday night's game against the Bulls. Krstic, wearing jeans and a sweater and lounging on a leather sofa, said that he was over the initial shock and that he felt good mentally and physically. Krstic is to have surgery Wednesday, and he said that doctors told him he could be playing basketball again by June or July.  The swingman Bernard Robinson, who was acquired from the Charlotte Bobcats for point guard Jeff McInnis on Wednesday, joined the Nets on Friday. He was inactive for the game against the Bulls.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Keep Composure and Pull Off Comeback

content.text: On the play that essentially decided the game, Knicks guard Stephon Marbury did everything right defensively. He stepped around a high screen set by Ruben Patterson, Milwaukee's muscular forward, and forced the right-handed guard Mo Williams to dribble left.  But Williams, who had missed the previous nine games with a sprained left shoulder, made an off-balance 20-footer Sunday to give the Bucks a 4-point lead with 3.1 seconds to play. That basket, and a foul shot that Williams was actually trying to miss, enabled the Bucks to overcome 17 fourth-quarter points from Jamal Crawford and hold off the Knicks, 107-105, at the Bradley Center.  ''He made a good shot,'' Marbury said of Williams. ''I wouldn't call it a lucky shot.''  Had the Knicks defended the first 47 minutes 50 seconds as well as Marbury did on that play, the struggling Bucks might not have broken their six-game losing streak, and Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas might not have turned his postgame news conference into a lamentation on his team's failure to make free throws.  The Knicks finished 14 of 24 from the line (58.3 percent) after a 10-for-20 start. The numbers 14 and 24 remained on the locker room dry erase board long after Thomas pulled on his dark wool overcoat and headed for the team bus.  ''Our inability to convert when we get to the foul line is killing us right now, and all season,'' Thomas said.  Center Eddy Curry, who shot 6 for 9 and had 15 points in his return from a strained left calf muscle, and the backup forward David Lee (19 points, 14 rebounds) gave the Knicks a strong presence inside.  But Thomas and his players used words like ''strange'' and ''weird'' to describe a game that the Knicks, who gave up too many layups and easy baskets inside, nearly pulled out.  ''It was definitely a strange game from the beginning,'' Curry said. ''It wasn't one of those games where we were clicking early and rode a wave the whole game.''  The Knicks' performance mirrored that of Crawford, who was ineffective until the final quarter.  Coming off his career-high 52 points against Miami on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, Crawford did not touch the ball the first four minutes as the Knicks worked it inside to Curry. Then he missed his first six shots.  The Knicks trailed by as many as 11 before Crawford scored his first basket, a pumping layup from the right with 1 minute 12 seconds left in the first half.  ''I think the first game after a game like that is probably the hardest,'' Crawford said, referring to his big night. ''By my teammates kept encouraging me.''  When the fourth quarter began, the Knicks trailed, 78-69, and Crawford was 3 of 13 from the field. But over the next 10 minutes, he and the rookie reserve forward Renaldo Balkman led the Knicks back.  Crawford scored 14 points, including two 3-pointers, while Balkman added 8 points inside and a block. Then, two foul shots and a 3-pointer by Marbury cut the Bucks' lead to 102-100 with a minute to play.  But Williams, who finished with 30 points and 10 assists, proved too tough. He had a hand in Milwaukee's final 11 points. Over the last 4:03, Williams hit three jumpers and one free throw and had two assists.  Williams and Marbury exchanged baskets before Williams sank the critical 20-footer. The Knicks called timeout to advance the ball to the forecourt, where Mardy Collins inbounded to Crawford, who made a quick catch-and-shoot 3-pointer. Even though no Knick touched the ball before Crawford, the game clock ran down to 0.8 from 3.1.  Thomas argued that the play could not have taken that much time, but the officials let it stand.  ''It was their call,'' Thomas said.  Crawford fouled Williams on the inbounds play, leaving four-tenths of a second left.  Then, more weirdness. Williams missed the first of two free throws. On the second, he stepped to the left side of the foul line and tried bank the ball off the rim to keep play alive and run out the clock. Instead, he swished it.  ''I guess I'm too good of a free-throw shooter,'' Williams said, laughing.  After another Knicks timeout, Crawford shot an air ball on a turnaround 3-point attempt from the left corner. The shot would not have counted because Crawford stepped on the sideline as he spun.  ''I was just trying to rush to get it up there,'' Crawford said.  Marbury was left to explain how the Knicks, after routing the Heat with Dwyane Wade and Shaquille O'Neal, could lose to an undersized Milwaukee team without its leading scorer, Michael Redd (strained left patellar tendon). The Bucks had been 0-4 at the Bradley Center in January after going 7-0 in December.  ''We have to come out more prepared at the beginning of the game to make the plays, so we don't put ourselves in these situations,'' Marbury said.  REBOUNDS  Guard NATE ROBINSON had a halfcourt 3-point basket at the end of the first quarter disallowed on video review, because the clock showed time had expired before the ball left his hands. Undaunted, Robinson tried again just before halftime and made it from three-quarters court, easily beating the buzzer.  The Knicks deactivated KELVIN CATO to activate EDDY CURRY.  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Clock Expires As Comeback By Knicks Falls Short

content.text: A gloom descended on the Rangers late in a 3-1 loss to Atlanta yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, where the crowd melted away and the team limped into the All-Star Game break with the momentum of a stalled car.  This seemed worse than just another loss. The Rangers have lost four of their past five games, but they were tied, 1-1, going into the third period yesterday. And they remain in a full-scale search for answers.  Although they seem to have stanched the worst of their defensive problems lately, the Rangers are now having difficulty scoring. On the power play, they pass the puck excessively and routinely scamper back to retrieve it. If opponents slow Jaromir Jagr, then the rest of the Rangers offer few options.  ''It just seems right now the team's off balance, the power play's off balance, the lines seem disjointed,'' forward Brendan Shanahan said. ''Sometimes it's a good time to step back, have a bit of a break and come back recharged.''  Last season, the Rangers were a hot team going into the Olympic break and cooled off when they returned. Going into the All-Star Game this season, the Rangers would need Freon to lower their temperature any further. At 23-21-4, they are fighting to hang on to a playoff position.  Meanwhile, Atlanta cruises into the break in first place in the Southeast Division at 27-15-8, a young, entertaining team with few of the Rangers' worries.  Shanahan will be the Rangers' only representative at the All-Star Game on Wednesday in Dallas. It is a fitting honor for a 19-year veteran with 24 goals, tied for the team lead, but it comes with its own contradictions. Shanahan remains one of the Rangers' great projects because they have failed to put an effective line around him. Of Shanahan's goals, 12 have come on power plays. He has not scored at even strength since Dec. 9.  The Rangers signed Shanahan, who has 622 career goals, in the off-season as a free agent. But they cannot find the right person to pass him the puck.  Coach Tom Renney has tried several players on the line with Shanahan, including Petr Prucha, Jarkko Immonen, Martin Straka, Marcel Hossa and Jason Ward. Center Matt Cullen has been moved off the line, back on the line and shoved over to the left wing. Against Atlanta, Jason Krog, claimed off waivers from the Thrashers on Jan. 12, was thrown between Cullen and Shanahan at center.  That line had a few scoring chances.  ''It's our first game together and who knows if we'll have a second game together,'' Shanahan said. ''It's just about developing some chemistry and getting results.''  Shanahan is the star, but one without a proper setup man.  ''You'd like to think it's in your lineup, but it's possible that it's not,'' Renney said. ''You can guess your way through that only so long. Bottom line is, we have to have results from that position.''  Renney will spend at least part of the break in Hartford, searching for answers among the Rangers' minor leaguers, but the Rangers are also looking around the league as the Feb. 27 trade deadline approaches. They are reported to be in line to acquire the often-injured center Peter Forsberg from Philadelphia if the Flyers decide to trade him.  ''Obviously there has to be something missing,'' Jagr said. ''If there wasn't anything missing, we would have a better record.''  Jagr, with 17 goals and a team-leading 59 points, has tried to do the heavy lifting. Against Atlanta, he scored the Rangers' goal on a spectacular move, putting an unstoppable shot on Kari Lehtonen 8 minutes 7 seconds into the first period.  The Thrashers had a pretty goal in the first period, on a shot by Ilya Kovalchuk, and an ugly one in the third, when defenseman Niclas Havelid bounced a puck off the back of goaltender Henrik Lundqvist. In the second, Lundqvist had kept the Rangers alive by stopping a penalty shot by Marian Hossa, but Hossa added an empty-net goal in the final minute.  All the Rangers got was an emptier feeling for their week off.  HOCKEY
content.title: With Loss, Rangers Limp Into Break

content.text: Fists flew, mayhem reigned and the Knicks were sentenced to three weeks of unmitigated suffering for their transgressions. Wasn't that the idea when the National Basketball Association penalized them for brawling with the Denver Nuggets last month?  The punishment was swift: suspensions for four players, totaling 21 games and $253,000 in lost salary, and a $500,000 fine for the franchise. But the last of those suspensions has ended, and the Knicks appear no worse for the experience. In fact, they are unmistakably better off.  The Knicks won 6 of 10 games during the suspensions. Their enigmatic point guard, Stephon Marbury, found his stride again. Their new sensation at power forward, David Lee, became more sensational. Jamal Crawford became a force again. Eddy Curry flirted with dominance.  Like unruly students -- as if they were the N.B.A.'s own Bart Simpson -- the Knicks finished writing, ''I will not start brawls that embarrass the league'' 1,000 times on the chalkboard, only to end up smirking and oddly valiant when it was all over.  ''We're a better team now,'' Marbury said Tuesday, echoing the unanimous sentiment of Knicks' players and coaches.  The why and the how of the Knicks' improbable turnaround with a depleted roster depends on who is explaining it. But there is no debating the bottom line.  The Knicks had not won six games in any 10-game stretch since last January. They needed 17 games to earn their first six victories this season. Their record after the Dec. 16 brawl was 9-17. They are a more palatable 15-21 heading into Wednesday night's home game against the Philadelphia 76ers -- the Knicks' first game with a full roster since the fight.  Lee, who averaged 10.3 points and 14.1 rebounds during the past 10 games, recalled the daunting feeling the Knicks faced after the suspensions were issued. They were about to play the Utah Jazz at Madison Square Garden, and had only eight players in uniform. In addition to the suspended players (Nate Robinson, Jared Jeffries, Mardy Collins and Jerome James), the Knicks were missing two injured starters, Quentin Richardson and Steve Francis.  ''We had hardly enough guys to do two-line layups,'' Lee said of the pregame warm-ups. ''It seemed like we were rebounding, dribbling out and then dribbling back in to shoot our own layups.''  The Knicks beat the Jazz in overtime that night, with Lee passing to Marbury for a driving layup at the buzzer.  ''I think you saw the true character of our team that day,'' Lee said.  In the next days, the Knicks also beat Charlotte (in double overtime) and two Eastern Conference powers, Chicago (in regulation) and Detroit (in triple overtime). There was a sense among the players that the brawl, the suspensions and the universal criticism directed at them had made the Knicks a more tightly knit group.  Coach Isiah Thomas has consistently dismissed that idea, and he did again Tuesday.  ''We didn't need that fight to remind us that we were against the world,'' said Thomas, who insisted that even before the fight, the Knicks ''were right on the verge of starting to play well.''  ''I don't think it's because you got into a fight or something like that that made you play well,'' Thomas said. ''A lot of teams get into fights and a lot of people get into fights, and that don't make them play well.''  The Nuggets illustrate that point. They have lost 6 of 10 games -- 5 straight at one point -- since the brawl, despite acquiring Allen Iverson from the 76ers after the incident. The Nuggets' incumbent star, Carmelo Anthony, has another five games left in his 15-game suspension.  Coincidentally or not, the Knicks' resurgence has spread into the stands. In four home games since the brawl, attendance has averaged 18,732, with two sellouts (19,763). In the previous 14 home games, the Knicks averaged 17,579, with three sellouts (including the night of the brawl).  The dynamic at the Garden has changed so drastically that Thomas -- who earlier this season chided fans for booing too much -- now says the Knicks have regained their home-court advantage.  ''Definitely looking forward to getting back in the Garden,'' he said. ''The last couple games we've played there have been exciting, the fans have been great. And they've given us a big lift and given us a big advantage at home.''  REBOUNDS  Knicks officials and the agent for Steve Francis denied a report that they were discussing a contract buyout. ''That's never been discussed,'' Isiah Thomas, the team president, said in response to the report in Tuesday's New York Post. Jeff Fried, who represents Francis, called the report ''a false statement'' and said that buyout talks ''have never even been contemplated.'' Francis is making $15 million this season and is owed $34.5 million over the next two seasons. Speculation about Francis's future has gone on for months, because he has a large contract and has been an awkward fit next to Stephon Marbury. The speculation grew last week when Francis left the team to rehabilitate his sore right knee in Houston. Thomas said he expected Francis to return once the knee was ready. ''If it's up to me, he'd do it tomorrow,'' Thomas said, adding, ''We definitely want him back.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Suspensions After Brawl Animated the Knicks
